bio: Kind of easy & minimal recipes A lot of things in bowls Travel on @loocheeya Saveur & Esquire UK’s Top Food Instagrams 🍘 Boston

posts.description:
Garlic Confit
_____________
In a baking dish, combine peeled garlic from about 8 heads with a few thyme sprigs and bay leaves. Cover completely with olive oil. Bake in a 350° oven for about 45 min - 1 hour until garlic cloves are softened and fragrant. Remove from oven and let cool. Your kitchen will smell amazing. Store garlic in an airtight container in the fridge, making sure to cover everything completely with the scented oil.
____________
Both garlic confit and oil are great with roasted veg, pastas, pizzas, spread on toast, etc. Or eaten straight out of a jar, no one will judge. Recipe inspired by the @gjelinarestaurant cookbook.

Caramelized Honey Nut and Seed Tart, with walnut (or pecan), hazelnut, pistachio, sliced almonds, sunflower seeds in a easy-to-make buttery eggy press-on crust. No rolling necessary!
_____________
Made this tart three years in a row for Christmas, and it’s always been a hit. It’s indulgent, not too sweet and feels slightly healthy. 😊✨🎄🎉 Make this a part of holiday tradition as well!

🍚Homemade fried rice with both roasted and smoked tofu. With egg, peas, ginger, scallion, cilantro, sesame oil, soy sauce, sriracha.
_______________________________

Noodles with a simple and addictive sauce. Mix sesame paste or tahini, sesame oil, soy sauce or tamari, chinkiang vinegar and a crushed garlic to taste. Add more sesame oil or a splash of hot water to make it runny if needed. Toss sauce with your choice of Asian wheat or rice noodles, top with shredded chicken or tofu, cucumbers, scallions, sesame seeds and a healthy dollop of @lahttsauce chili oil sauce.

__________________

Crisp up some prosciutto in a pan, render out some fat. Set prosciutto aside, sauté nameko mushrooms in the same pan until browned. Toss everything with cooked pasta, top with a fried egg, parsley, chili pepper flakes, salt and pepper to taste.

The smoothest best hummus in the land. Topped with lamb, pine nuts and peas, makes a satisfying lunch. @dizengoff_philly
____________
Israeli couscous salad with tomatoes, sugar snaps, cucumbers, olives, feta, a poop ton of parsley, red wine vinegar, olive oil, spiced up w/ Aleppo pepper. Also great with an egg or smoked fish.

Homemade potstickers/gyoza with pork, shrimp, shiitake mushroom, Napa cabbage, ginger, scallion. Recipe in link/stories.
________________
Served with the gochujang-based ssäm sauce from @momolongplay. Spicy and mouth-wateringly (is that a word?!) tangy.

Some comfort food to cure the Sunday night blues. Fried rice made with bacon hot dog(!) from @vtsmoke, egg, peas, crushed ginger, leftover rice, topped with chives, sesame oil and sriracha. And a nice warm mug of barley tea.
______________________

Fish cake noodles with a shrimp heart 🍤💕 because 'tis the season.
___________________________
Afternoon snack: Figs on ricotta on wasa crispbread. Drizzled with @caoliveranch olive oil, lava salt.

Arctic char and peppercorn-crusted filet of foal 🐴 @olafshus. It was deliciously prepared--little less gamey than lamb and has more flavor than beef.
___________

Pork dumplings, doused with soy sauce, Chinkiang vinegar, chili oil, cucumber, cilantro -- sort of inspired by @xianfoods in NYC. Btw, if anyone has a good Xi'an style lamb dumpling recipe, please lemme know! 😊🙏🏼

Yes, an avocado toast. So original 🙈. But it's on @clearflourbread's pain de mie so it's that much better.
Also, there's only a few more days to vote on @saveurmag's

😆🍅 Souvenir from SF
____________

👋🏼👋🏼 Welcome new friends! Thank you so much for following along. 😊 Also, thank you to those who have been voting for me on @saveurmag's Blog Awards in the Best Food Instagram category. I'm humbled to be among the other finalists and truly appreciate your vote. You can continue to vote until 8/31, and can do so as many times as you'd like! Profile is in the link. Thank you!! 🙌🏼. In the meantime, here's something healthy for you. A quick noodle soup for lunch or dinner: chicken broth, sardines (or whatever protein you prefer), with seaweed, pea shoots sautéed with garlic, chopped radish greens kimchi on rice noodles, topped with a little ikura, Japanese fish cake 🍥, and sesame oil. Chili oil, sriracha or any hot sauce works well too! Enjoy and thanks again!
__________________

Ikura (salmon roe) from @newdealfishmarket. They're like bright little gems and goes well with rice. They're already briny, but I like to dip them in soy sauce anyway.
_______________

Making tartine with French butter from @formaggiosouthend and cinnamon pear jam from Vermont. Coffee and milk tea

______________________

Celebrating snow (and pi day) with donuts from @unionsquaredonuts, vanilla bean and brown butter hazelnut.
__________________________

Pan-seared yellowtail snapper with a salsa verde of parsley, banana peppers, lemon, garlic, coriander and topped w toasted pine nuts .
_______________
Recipe inspired by the broiled red snapper w za’atar salsa verde on @bonappetitmag

Homemade summer rolls with avocado, cucumbers, chicken and cilantro. Chunky peanut butter, grated ginger and hoisin sauce - mix w a little hot water to loosen.
____________________

Weekend cabin fever baking. ❄️🍪 Pecan, oats, coconut and chopped dark chocolate chunks. There's definitely more chocolate than cookie dough.
__________________________

🍜 Rice noodles stir-fried with chicken, carrots, celery, egg, ginger, garlic, soy sauce, oyster sauce, shaoxing wine, lots of turmeric and curry powder. Tossed in scallions and pineapple at the end, drizzled with sriracha and sesame oil.
______________

Shrimp Fried Rice
_____________
Ingredients: egg, chopped shrimp, rice, sliced scallion (greens and white parts separated), minced ginger, sesame oil. Any fried rice recipe is a delicious way to use leftover rice.
_______________
Have all your ingredients ready as the whole dish comes together pretty quickly.
In a small hot pan, sauté chopped raw shrimp in a little oil until mostly cooked through. Set aside in a bowl. In the same pan, fry-scramble a few eggs until it’s mostly set but a little runny. Break apart into large pieces with a wooden spoon. Set aside. In a separate large wok or pan, heat a generous amount of veg oil on med-high until smoking. Stir-fry minced ginger and sliced scallion whites until fragrant, 1-2 min. Add in rice (must use leftover rice so the end results won’t be soggy--if planning ahead, cook rice and refrigerate at least a day ahead.) Let rice warm up in the pan and cook for about 3-4 minutes, occasionally toss things around. Put in the cooked shrimp and stir-fry for about another minute. When everything is super hot, season with soy sauce or just salt to keep things gluten-free. Just before serving, stir in the cooked eggs and scallion greens. Add a drizzle of sesame oil and a sprinkle of ground white pepper. Serve with your fave hot sauce.

Meal-prepping for the busy week ahead. Homemade potstickers (left) and wontons (right). 🥟 Wrap, freeze separately, then place in a tupperware or gallon ziploc in the freezer and you’ll have a quick last-minute nourishing meal in no time. Both potstickers and wontons can be cooked from frozen.

🍅👋🏼 The first day of autumn tomorrow means saying goodbye to good tomatoes until next summer.
____________________

Tofu Kimchi Stew: made with chicken broth, garlic, ginger, gochujang, soy sauce, simmered with daikon, homemade kimchi, silken tofu, topped with scallion. It’s tangy, spicy, satisfying and cures what ails you 🌶🍲(aka a hangover 🙃). Full recipe on @healthy_ish and @bonappetitmag

Doing a little clean-ish eating this week: sautéed pickled mustard greens, silken tofu, chicken broth, chili oil, sesame oil, scallions
___________________________

Homemade breakfast sausage for dinner 🍳
_______________
With your hands (gloved hands, maybe) lightly mix 2lbs. ground pork, some dried thyme, a bit of nutmeg, lots of minced fresh sage, 1 Tbsp brown sugar (or maple syrup), a dash of cayenne and red chili pepper flakes (if you want things spicy). Salt and pepper to taste. Form into patties of your preferred size. Fry on medium heat until cooked through and golden, about 4-5 min on each side. Serve with fried eggs, tucked into a flaky biscuit, rice, or whatever you’d like. Real maple syrup as a dipping sauce won’t hurt either.

Grilled pork banh mi from @phoviets. 👌🏼Perfection.
A big thank you to everyone who has voted for me for @saveurmag's blog awards! You can continue to do so until tomorrow (8/31)! 😊 Thank you for your continued support and for following along!

Weekend food project idea: Folding traditional pleated Chinese dumpling. Filling made with ground pork, chopped scallions, grated ginger, chopped wood ear, white pepper, sesame oil, soy sauce. Mix vigorously and let sit overnight before wrapping--apparently that's supposed to make the meat texture firm up. Have fun!

_____________________
Sort of autumn-ish colors on a plate: pink, yellow and regular oyster mushrooms pan-fried in duck fat, pancetta, pappardelle pasta, topped with butter-fried sage leaves

Gochujang blistered haricot vert with radish, carrot, black vinegar garlic slaw, topped with a fried poached egg. Arnold Palmer made with pu-erh tea, apple cider vinegar and honey. Genius. @ourcookquest @niccomuratore

🌞🐟🌮Summer = Fish Tacos
Made with dogfish or cape shark, a perfectly delicious underused firm fish. Cut into 2-3 inch pieces, lightly dust with flour seasoned with s/p and whatever spice mix you want. Pan fry with neutral oil on med-high until lightly golden for about 2-3 mins a side. Tuck into some charred tortillas, top with chopped tomatoes + onion/shallot, quick-pickled cabbage, drizzle with @vermontcreamery crème fraîche mixed with lime juice as a sort of lime-crema. Top with cilantro and serve with hot sauce and more lime.
___________
Go to @redsbest @bostonpublicmarket to get local super fresh dogfish, which helps to sustain the livelihoods of small boat New England fishermen.
_________
Check out my IG story to hear Chef @jeremy_sewall and Jared, CEO & owner of @redsbest talk about identifying your fish. And thank you @allheartpr for the invite! 😊🐟🦑
Clam toast with pancetta. So good when the olive oil-fried toast soaks up all the broth. Recipe from the Sept '17 issue of @bonappetitmag

🇮🇸🍦When in Iceland, licorice and dandelion ice cream
___________

Shakshuka (eggs poached in a spicy homemade tomato sauce). Based on the recipe from the @sofrabakery cookbook. Serve with zhoug. Perfect for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. The pillowy pita rolls are from Sofra itself because I have to leave some things for the experts to make ☺️

Kimchi Fried Rice
__________________
Chop, mince and prep ingredients ahead of time because everything comes together pretty quickly. Results: a tangy, satisfying bowl of umami amazingness.
__________________
Heat oil in a large pan (or a wok) on medium-high. Add in minced ginger and the white parts of a couple scallions. Cook until fragrant, about 1 min. Add in your desired amount of leftover rice. (Must use leftover rice so things don’t get mushy or soggy.) Break up large clumps of rice with wet hands or jab with a wooden spoon/spatula if needed. Use a spatula and press everything down in the pan so the rice heats up evenly and kinda gets a little crispy. When warmed through, stir in chopped kimchi and your veg and/or protein of choice. Toss everything around, add in some kimchi liquid, season with salt or soy sauce to taste. But be careful because kimchi juice is pretty salty on its own. Before serving, drizzle everything with toasted sesame oil, a few grinds of white pepper, top with the green parts of the scallions, sesame seeds, and a fried egg.

Cantonese-inspired Pork Shoulder Roast, Hot Rice and Veg
_______________
Mix well equal parts of ¼ cup hoisin sauce, soy sauce (or tamari to make it g-free), honey, Shaoxing wine (or unseasoned Chinese cooking wine), and 1 tsp Chinese 5-spice powder. Marinate a 3 lb boneless pork shoulder in the mixture for about 24 hours. Remove from the fridge 1 hour before roasting.
_______________
Heat oven to 300ºF, put pork in roasting pan, reserve marinade for basting later. Tightly cover the pork with foil and roast for about 2 hours. Remove foil, do a little basting and roast uncovered for about another 2 hours. Then continue roasting and basting about every 10 minutes for an hour longer until the pork is coated in an appetizing dark shiny glaze. Things should be super tender and shreddy.
_______________
Carefully remove from oven, let rest for about 20 minutes, shred the pork with fork and eat alongside hot rice and veg of your choice. (or wrap the shredded pork in a taco or burrito).
_______________
Recipe adapted from Lucky Peach 101 Easy Asian Recipes by Peter Meehan @greasetrap.

A dessert you can whip out in about an hour that looks a little “fancy” but comes together easily. This is an Apple-Almond Galette, made with store-bought puff pastry (Dufour) and almond cream you can make ahead of time. I used a pink lady apple here, but you can use whatever fruit that can handle the oven. The galette is also great the next day as a luxurious breakfast or snack.
___________
Inspired by the apricot-almond galette recipe from @bonappetitmag.
Street food in the Tohoku region: charcoal-broiled rice cakes (mochi), basted with shoyu and topped with a perfect little piece of nori.
Black (beluga) lentil salad with cucumbers, homemade pickled onion, topped with an @vitalfarms egg.

Pork carnitas tacos with avocado, salsa verde from @traderjoes, shallots, lime, cilantro. Juicy, simple, and flavorful.
__________________
To make carnitas: Sprinkle 1 ½ teaspoon or about ½ Tbsp kosher salt all over a 3 - 4lbs. pork shoulder and place in a heavy-bottomed enameled cast iron dutch oven. Add in about 1 - 1 ½ cups of chicken stock, a bay leaf if you fancy, cover and place in a 300°F oven (lower-middle rack) until pork is tender and shreds easily, about 2 hours. Check and rotate pork occasionally, add a bit more broth if things are a little dry. Slow roast a little longer if things aren’t falling-apart-tender. Once pork is tender, you can shred and serve as is over rice, in a burrito or any preferred carbs. Or, put some chunks of pork and a bit of the pan juice in a skillet and cook over high heat until pork begin to fry in its own fat and becomes golden and crispy. Then serve in tacos.

A winter lobster roll--without the ocean views and seagulls overhead--is still a good lobster roll. Fresh lobster, seasoned with lemon juice, celery seeds, minced celery, a small touch of mayo, topped with chives, packed into a toasted buttered hot dog bun. Need potato chips.
___________________________
Warm blanket in bowl form 🍲 Homemade pork wontons in chicken broth.

Can't ever say no to oysters (Island Creeks) @selectoysterbar
_____________

Testing out some pork and shrimp wontons wrapped from the weekend. Served with chili oil, seaweed, noodles and chicken broth, especially good on a raw windy day when you're also rocking a sore throat 🤒🍲. Kimchi and a soy-chinkiang vinegar dipping sauce on the side.
________________________
Steak and spring veg (asparagus and peas) with a nose-tingling Dijon mustard sauce. A super delicious one-skillet supper recipe from @bonappetitmag, NY strip steak from @savenorscambridge.

Almost mid-week cocktail hour snacks. Moon drop grapes and brown sugar fennel salami from @tastysaltedpigparts
__________________

Chicken tikka masala and basmati rice from @bukharabistro. Still very good as leftovers. 🙌🏽 Topped it wth some charred leek greens.
_________________

Flounder roe seared in butter
____________
Melt butter on medium, carefully lay flounder roe or any sac of fish roe in pan. Warning: it may spatter like crazy. Wear goggles if necessary 🤓. Cook undisturbed for about 2-3 mins on one side until golden brown, then carefully turn and fry for another minute. You may find bits of roe around your kitchen later from all the spattering 😝. The results are rewarding though...the texture is firm and has a mild oceany flounder flavor. Serve with Parmesan and lemon. Makes a great inexpensive appetizer--this lobe of roe is less than $2 from @newdealfishmarket and is satisfying enough for two people.

San Francisco: so many great places to eat, so little time. After almost a week of delicious gluttony, it's time for some simpler and lighter meals. Here is salmon from @redsbest, so fresh, simply pan-seared with a side of charred green beans & shallots, and a tahini-lemon-parsley-olive oil sauce.
Also, when you have a chance, please vote on @saveurmag's blog awards! Link is in the profile. Thanks!!

Soy pickle brined fried chicken with sourdough garlic chives waffle, topped with mango chanterelle chutney. Smoked maple syrup on the side. We're still talking about this dish and thinking about that smoked maple syrup 😋. This entire dish was SO GOOD!! @ourcookquest @niccomuratore

It’s not always about capturing the perfect subject to ‘gram. Sometimes it’s the behind-the-scenes experience and who you share it with, that matters more. These 🍦🍦🍦 were consumed after we collectively demolished 200+ mini bowls of soba in Morioka. And it must’ve been the cute old Japanese lady working the soft-serve machine for the first time. 😉🤗 @cheapcourage @thesocialpause @tommylundberg
A pre-dinner snack plate: Castelvetrano olives, summer sausage from @vtsmoke, and Hervé Mons cow's milk triple-crème called St. Nuage, appropriately named for its cloud-like texture ☁️

Farmer's market strawberries macerated in brown sugar and a sprinkling of rose water.
_____
Serve with dark chocolate or whipped cream or a cold glass of bubbly or all of the above. Easy summertime dessert.

Lime Pickle-Roasted Chicken Thighs with Potatoes and Watercress--recipe from @bonappetitmag. I used arugula here instead. Lime pickle can be found in Indian grocery stores. Chicken marinated in mayo to encourage browning. I used @sirkensingtons vegan mayonnaise made from aquafaba (chickpea cooking water) not chemicals and weird additives. The dish is super flavorful and puckery. 🍗🥔Search for the recipe on @bonappetitmag online!
Easy Monday dinner: Japanese wheat noodles, sautéed bok choy, smoked trout, chicken broth, scallions.

Salmon Broiled with Miso: - Combine 1/3 cup sugar, 1 cup miso, 1/2 cup mirin in small saucepan over low heat, bring to almost a boil, stirring occasionally. Mixture will be thin-ish. Remove from heat.
- Place 1 to 1 1/2lb. salmon on a skillet or baking dish, spoon half the sauce on top, broil 3-4 inches from heat source until sauce begins to bubble and brown slightly, about 4 min. Carefully take out the pan, spoon more sauce over fish. You may have extra sauce left over...save in a jar for another use. - Continue to broil until golden brown, about 4-5 min, adjust heat/rack position if sauce is browning too quickly. - Remove from oven, serve with lots of white rice 🍚 🐟 and veggies for a complete healthy meal. Salmon from @redsbest at @bostonpublicmarket. Freshest of the fresh.
____________________________
Salmon, seared shishito pepper, cucumber and herbs salad with a fish sauce-lime-Thai bird chili vinaigrette. Recipe inspired by @bonappetitmag, which uses squid instead.

White Bean and Ham Soup with carrots, onions, garlic, coriander, chicken/ham hock stock
__________________
On medium heat, warm up a bit of oil. When shimmering, add in chopped onion and carrots, stir occasionally until softened a bit, about 5-6 minutes. Add in a minced garlic, a tsp. of ground coriander, a sprinkle of dried thyme (or add a couple sprigs of fresh ones), stir for about a minute until fragrant. Add in 3 cans of drained and rinsed white beans, or the equivalent of beans cooked from dried. Then pour in about a quart (or a little more) of chicken or ham hock stock. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for about 15-20 minutes.
__________________
When carrots and beans are softened to your liking, removed thyme sprigs if you used fresh ones. Add in cubed ham, warm for a few minutes longer, taste, season with salt if needed, add a sprinkle of cayenne for heat or stir in a dollop of creme fraiche for richness. Top with sliced scallions and enjoy. Warm and nourishing on a snowy winter night 🍲🤗

A homemade riff on Korean barbecue. To make the marinade: grate 1/4 pear, crush 1 garlic clove, 2 Tbsp soy sauce, 1 Tbsp each of gochugaru, grated ginger, light brown sugar, and sesame oil. Slice about 1 lb. of hanger steak (or chicken or pork loin) into thin strips and add to marinade. Mix around and let sit at room temp for 30 min or chill up to 8 hours. Heat oil in large skillet over medium-high. Remove meat from marinade and season lightly with salt. Work in batches, cook meat in a single layer without turning until browned, about 1-2 min. Turn and cook for 2 min longer until cooked through and crisped at edges. Continue with another batch, add more oil if needed. Serve with hot rice, more sesame oil (optional) and sliced scallions. Recipe from @bonappetitmag. So easy and tasty.
_____________________

Crispy chickpeas with sautéed kale, topped with a fried egg. Super easy and quick weeknight dinner inspired by @bonappetitmag. For the chickpeas: Rinse a 15oz. can of chickpeas, pat dry. Heat olive oil in a skillet over medium heat, add chickpeas, crushed garlic, salt. I added a dash of cayenne and za'atar because 💃🏻. Stir occasionally until chickpeas are crisped and sort of split open, about 10-15 min. Can stir in chopped mixed tender herbs such as parsley, chives, etc. to make them all herby.
___________________________

🍞Cleaning out the fridge type of lunch
______________

🍾 Lambrusco to celebrate @epekho's birthday!
______________

For a quick and nourishing meal, cook up some homemade (or store bought) wontons and top it on organic ramen and miso broth. The other add-ins I have here are furikake, scallions, chili pepper and sliced raw garlic cured in Chinkiang vinegar. Major coziness in a bowl 🍜 Simple and satisfying.

Congee with fish balls (魚蛋粥) 🍲 topped with chili oil, sesame oil, preserved bamboo shoots and tons of white pepper. Perfect for a -9°F day yesterday 2.14.16
______________

This easy flatbread recipe is for people who aren’t big on making bread. It has yogurt in the dough which keeps things moist and gives it a slight tang. The flatbread comes together in minimal time and goes great with this yogurt-cucumber-herb dip or anything you want to pile on top!
___________________
Search ‘falafel-spiced tomato and chickpeas on flatbread’ for the flatbread and yogurt sauce recipes on @bonappetitmag

🥟Homemade frozen gyoza/potstickers coming in handy on a busy weeknight. Stuffed with ground pork, shrimp, Napa cabbage, scallion, wood ear, white pepper, soy sauce, sesame oil. Wrap, freeze separately on a floured sheet pan, then throw in a Tupperware of freezer bag.
_________
Cook from frozen: preheat cast iron pan on medium, add oil, place frozen potstickers flat side down, cook for about 4-5 min until bottoms are golden. Add about 4 tbsp water, cover and let steam/cook through for about 3-4 min on high. Remove cover, cook on medium for another 2-3 min to evaporate remaining water and recrisp the bottom. Enjoy with Chinkiang vinegar-soy sauce dip and sriracha.
_________
If you scroll down back to Sept 2016, there’s a little video on how to wrap these 🥟🥟✌🏼😊

Dal (yellow split peas), spiced with coriander, turmeric, ginger, garlic, cardamom, onion, on a bed of fluffy basmati rice. Topped with yogurt seasoned with salt and red onions pickled with lime juice and zest.

Delicious, healthy and super satisfying.
______________________
Recipe from @bonappetitmag

🦀 Tis the season for soft-shell crabs
____________

Niçoise salad - ingredients mostly from the farmer's market, with dark purple tomatoes and the coolest potatoes that are red on the outside and inside. Salmon from @redsbest. Dressing: anchovy-Dijon-red wine vinegar-lemon-olive oil vinaigrette
Soft shell crab roll; foie-ume-daikon maki @modernhonolulu; clear chopsticks (!) __________________________

Some fun guys (get it?) 😆🍄: hen of the woods, black trumpet, cinnamon caps and a couple oyster mushrooms from @sienafarms. 👌🏼 Pan fry in duck fat.
_____________
Baking to ward off the Sunday scaries. Why bake one banana bread when you can make two 🍌🍞 Recipe from the first @flourbakeryandcafe cookbook.

🥓🍳🥑🍞 Brunchie things. Farm eggs from the Esch Family Farm in Smyrna, Maine, bacon from @vtsmoke.
________________________

If you’re looking for a dessert other than pie for Thanksgiving (blasphemous, I know), try this pretty easy flambéed pear dessert.
_______
Caramelize butter, sugar and a pinch of salt with a peeled and cored pear, add a bit of pear brandy and flambé until the flames go out. Smoosh it onto some vanilla ice cream for a “rustic” look, spoon on some of the caramel and top with toasted almond slivers.
___________
Based off of a @healthy_ish and @bonappetitmag recipe online. Search for ‘Boozy Stovetop Pears.’ Enjoy and have a great Thanksgiving everyone! 🍐😋😊

The best malasadas in all the land from @leonardsbakeryhawaii.
___________________________
The most orange yolk from @vitalfarms and flavorful nameko mushrooms from @mycoterrafarm (sautéed in duck fat), available @copleysqfmkt and @brooklinefarmersmarket 🍳🍄

🍌🍞 Banana toast and iced latte
____________

Beautiful, pristine and delicious Peruvian scallop from @eat_fwd.

______________
Sending well wishes to everyone in Los Angeles 🙏🏼🙏🏼

🍤 Maine shrimp in season at Wulf's Fish Market
______________
Smoked salmon, crème fraîche, cucumber on leftover waffle, caperberries on the side.

When you want to eat some veg, but you don’t want to cook: on a mandoline, thinly slice fennel, beets, cucumbers, celery, whatever you want in a salad. Drizzle with lemon, olive oil, throw on some pine nuts/pistachio, shaved Parmesan, sea salt, pepper. Done!
Anchovies dissolved in olive oil, garlic, peas, linguine, lemon juice, lemon zest, Aleppo pepper from @sofrabakery, parmesan and ricotta from @richeeses.
Orange honey saffron madeleines, great for dessert, breakfast or afternoon tea. Recipe found @bonappetitmag, from @ottolenghi and @helen_goh_bakes’s book Sweet.

Turkey congee using leftover Thanksgiving turkey drumsticks and broth made from the carcass. Simmered with lemongrass and shiitake mushrooms. Topped with Thai chili peppers, ginger, and homemade salted duck egg yolk. Duck eggs from @savenorscambridge.
______________________

A riff on @bonappetitmag's porridge-y, congee-like Vietnamese chicken soup with rice--along with shiitake, wakame, seasoned with fish sauce, sesame oil, white pepper, and a boatload of scallions and ginger. This meal can practically cure what ails you and perfect for a cold rainy day.
_________________________

Ground pork stir-fried with baked tofu, ginger, garlic, scallions, hoisin sauce. Served with 🍚 rice, charred red cabbage, sesame oil and Chinese hot mustard
_____________

Dear little crabbie 🦀, I'm sorry I threw you into a pot of boiling water. Thank you for your deliciousness.
__________________________
Pretty pristine sardines. Perfect broiled or grilled, serve simply with sea salt and a squeeze of lemon

Roasted whole branzino, stuffed with a roughly chopped scallion-ginger-salt-oil mixture. Soy sauce-ume plum vinegar dipping sauce and more scallion ginger topping on the side. Rub branzino with oil, roast at 425° for about 15 min on middle rack, then transfer to upper third rack of the oven and broil for about 2-3 mins until skin begins to bubble and crisp.
_________________________

🍜🍤🍅 Tofu, shrimp, thick rice noodle in a tomato tom yum soup base. Perfect snow day lunch.
__________________________

Fried anchovies and chowder full of fresh clams @hogislandoysterco.
Also, welcome new followers and thank you everyone for your nominations and continued support! Please cast your vote for me, if you wish, on @saveurmag's Best Food Instagram award. Link is in the profile and vote as many times as you'd like! 😊 I'm grateful and truly humbled to be a finalist. Thank you!

🍜 Braised duck leg with thin egg noodles. Meat was tender, the broth was satisfying.
______________

On a ricotta kick lately--with squash blossoms, peaches and basil for a healthyish summery taco. Main ingredients from the Central Square farmer's market. •••
Also friends, don't forget to get the best peaches from @froghollowfarm and use the code FOODMINIMALIST to get 15% off your entire order online. Check out the sublime legendary Cal Reds via the link in my profile. They are indeed the best peaches you'll ever have. Enter promo code at checkout. Valid through Aug. 31 at 11:59pm PST. The peaches are tree-ripened, carefully hand-picked & hand-packed and shipped to you in 48 hours. 🍑🍑 Thank you, @froghollowfarm! Your peaches are truly amazing, and I'm so glad to have tried them.

Come check out my shrimp potstickers @redsbest in the @bostonpublicmarket this Friday 3/24 from 3-8pm! Filled with shrimp, cabbage, scallions, hand-wrapped just for you!
...
To wrap a "star" or "bow" shaped dumpling: Put a wrapper in your palm, fill with about 1 Tbsp of the shrimp mixture. Moisten all four edges with a little water. Bring together the opposite corners to form a triangle, but don’t close the other two sides. Bring up and fold the right side to the top and press close, gently squeeze out any air bubbles, repeat the same process with the left side, so the top of dumpling forms an ‘X’ and the bottom is relatively square-ish. Have fun!

Season chicken legs with salt and pepper, nestle snugly in a baking dish. Tuck in quartered shallots, whole unpeeled garlic all around, thyme sprigs (or dried thyme and bay leaf here). Seafood Chowder with mussels, countneck clams, squid, shrimp, white fish, guanciale, leeks, potatoes, cream, fish stock.
_____________
Dice up a thick slice of guanciale from @formaggiosouthend, pancetta or bacon (there's no such thing as too much) and render out some of the fat on low. When you feel like there's enough fat to cook the leeks, throw them in, stir for a min, then add chopped potatoes. Cook for about 5 mins, then add in about 4-6 cups of homemade fish stock. Simmer for about 15 min until potatoes are tender. Add in mussels and clams first since they take a bit longer to cook. When they've opened, add in the squid, shrimp and fish--simmer for about a min. Discard any shellfish that haven't opened. Turn heat off, season with salt and white pepper to taste, stir in a generous glug of cream, or if you wanna go lighter, use half and half. Add in some crème fraîche @vermontcreamery if you're feeling fancy. Serve with chives or scallions, lemon.
_____________
Fish stock: basically use fish bones, heads, and carcasses, shrimp shells, whole cleaned whiting or small fish, salmon collars, etc. Add in aromatics like shallots, onion, celery, fennel stems, bay leaf, tomato if you want. Cover with water and simmer on super low for about 1 to 1 1/2 hours. Stir occasionally. Strain through super fine sieve. It's so nourishing and good for you with all the omega 3s and collagen.

To cook the beef tongue 🐮👅: place in pot with aromatics such as carrots, onion, garlic, peppercorns and cover with water. Bring to boil and *simmer* for about 2-3 hours until tender. Take out of braising liquid. When it’s cool enough to touch, peel off the tough outer layer: important to do this while it’s still somewhat warm. Dice or slice, depending on what you prefer. The meat should be falling apart tender. Heat oil in a pan, season tongue with salt and smoked paprika and give it a good sear, about 2 min on med-high. It’ll be browned and melt-in-your-mouth delicious.

Take about a dozen plump dried shrimp (available in specialty Asian markets), soak in boiling water for about 25-30 mins. Drain. Cut 3-4 scallions into 2-3 inch pieces. Heat 4-5 tbsp neutral oil over med-high heat and cook the scallions until slightly golden. Toss in the soaked and drained dried shrimp and continue to fry until the scallions are pretty golden, the shrimp are a little chewy-crunchy and everything is very fragrant. Remove from heat and set pan aside.

Toss to mix well over medium heat, pour into warmed plate/bowl. Shave bottarga over pasta, sprinkle with lemon zest and serve immediately. To cook: preheat cast iron pan, add a good amount of oil and place dumpling (from frozen) flat side down in oil. Cook for about 3-4 min on med-high until bottoms are lightly golden. Add about a quarter cup of water, cover and steam on high for until water has fully evaporated. There will be a lot of loud sizzles. Uncover and let residual water evaporate. Turn heat to medium and cook for a few minutes longer to re-crisp the bottoms. Enjoy a hot sauce and a soy sauce-rice vinegar dip

Pat dry cleaned mackerel with paper towels. Put in a shallow dish and rub all over with sea salt flakes and a bit of neutral oil. Cover and refrigerate for about 30 mins. Heat broiler to high, shake off excess salt from fish and broil for about 10-15 mins. until the fish is cooked through and skin is crisped/browned. Serve with steamed rice, lemon or soy sauce, and simple greens. 🍚🐟

Carrots and scallions fresh from the farmer's market, covered in a delicious glaze. Cut 3 carrots and scallions into 3-inch batons. Heat veg oil in a cast iron over high heat, add carrots, stir-fry and let char a little. Then add scallions and stir fry until golden and slightly charred. Add 1 tbsp butter, 1 tbsp soy sauce and 1/2 tsp sugar. Toss and let it glaze all over the vegetables. Makes a pretty good side dish.

Brown Butter-Basted Steak
___________________
Season a 1 ½ lb. bone-in rib eye steak with kosher salt and let sit at room temp for an hour. In a hot cast iron pan, add oil and cook steak over medium-high heat, turning every 2 min or so, making sure to form a deep golden brown crust, about 8-10 min in total.
___________________
Add a good hunk of butter, a few sprigs of rosemary and a couple crushed garlic cloves. Carefully tilt pan towards you, spoon and continuously baste the steak with the rosemary, garlic and brown butter for about 1 min. Remove meat from heat and let rest for about 10 min. Slice against the grain, remove the bone and serve with some of the herb-infused brown butter and sea salt. The remaining garlic and crispy butter-fried rosemary also make a great steak companion.

Roasted branzino - rub both sides with grapeseed oil, or an oil with a medium-high smoke point, then stuff the cavity with scallions (or lemon slices or herbs), roast at 400° for about 20 min. Steaming the fish also works, but I didn't have a big enough vessel for it 😁. You can use any dipping sauce of your choice, but the soy sauce-hot oil approach is easy and flavorful. First, heat up 1-2 tbsp. of peanut or a neutral oil, then splash some soy sauce on the fish after it's done cooking. Top with julienned scallions and ginger, then carefully drizzle everything with the hot oil. The fun part is hearing the scallions sizzle. And picking apart the fish, of course.

To smash cucumbers: clean and if preferred, peel. Give them a couple good whacks with a rolling pin. The cucumbers should sort of split open a bit. Slice on the diagonal, sprinkle with a little salt and let it sit for about 5-10 min to draw out excess water from the cukes.

Chazuke (or ochazuke), is a simple Japanese dish of hot green tea, dashi, or broth poured over cooked rice. I used genmai cha (green tea with roasted rice), umeboshi (pickled plum) and furikake here, but you can add in a variety of your preferred toppings. Fish, nori and various pickles are popular choices 🤗🍚

A crunchy lemony salty salad.

Fava bean & ricotta on fried toast: De-pod fresh fava beans, blanch for about 3-4 min. Drain into an ice bath or very cold water. Pop beans out of their inner shell. Lightly mash with lemon juice, olive oil, salt and pepper. In a skillet, heat olive oil on medium and fry toast for about 3 min on each side. Top with ricotta, fava bean mixture, drizzle on more olive oil, sprinkle sea salt and Aleppo pepper.
Lamb + scallion dumplings with cumin, coriander, Szechuan peppercorns. Topped with chinkiang vinegar, soy sauce, scallions, cilantro, grated raw garlic, chili oil. Stir everything together and eat 😋

Chicken poached in coconut milk seasoned with lemongrass and fish sauce. Turmeric rice cooked in coconut milk, chicken broth, kaffir lime leaves. Squeeze lime all over, season with salt or fish sauce to taste. Also great served with the cucumber salad from the previous post.

🍳🧀 Easy weekend breakfast idea: sprinkle your preferred amount of shredded cheddar in a circle on a hot pan on low heat, let it melt a little, then crack an egg in the middle of the cheese, turn heat up to medium, sprinkle more cheese around the egg, cook until whites are mostly set, and the cheese edges are turning crispy. Eat with hot sauce.

Spaghetti with Clams: sauté sliced garlic in olive oil until fragrant, toss in a small chopped tomato, stir for a min. Add a generous splash of white wine and about a pound of scrubbed clams. Cover and cook on medium/low until clams open. Meanwhile, cook spaghetti according to package directions. Reserve pasta cooking water. When clams are done, add in the drained cooked pasta, toss to combine. Throw in some chopped parsley and continue to toss. Add some pasta cooking water if things look dry. Serve with a generous squeeze of lemon, a sprinkle of grated bottarga and a glass of cold crisp bubbly 🍾 Cape Cod littleneck clams from @redsbest

Purchased a little jar of hákarl (fermented shark) from @icelandairhotels in Vík, snuck it back home and finally had the courage to try it. When you first open the jar, it smelled like fish sauce, but when you inhale deeply, there's definitely a strong ammonia bite. The texture was squishy and chewy, the taste was, for a lack of a better description, super fishy and a bit bitter. Although it wasn't our favorite thing to eat, we're glad to have tried it. The Brennivín was delicious and helped to wash it all down.

An Improvised Seafood Chowder with cod, shrimp, wild mussels, countneck clams, squid 🐙🦐🐟🦑🍲
_______________
On low heat, cook a bit of chopped pancetta or bacon until some fat renders out. Increase heat to medium, stir in sliced shallots, fennel, chopped potatoes (minced celery also, if you prefer) and cook until a little softened. Add in a good amount of fish stock, about 4-6 cups (homemade is best, but your local fishmonger might sell some). Bring to a boil, then lower the heat, simmer until potatoes are cooked through, about 15-20 min.
_______________
Whatever seafood you use will cook relatively quickly. If using shellfish such as mussels and clams, simmer those first in the chowder base on med heat, until the shells have opened, discard those that don’t. Take cooked shellfish out and a divide amongst bowls. Cook the shrimp next for about a minute or two until they’re opaque. Remove and place in bowls as well. Lastly, stir in bite-sized pieces of cod or other white fish. They will cook in a minute. When opaque, stir in a good glug of heavy cream or a generous spoon of crème fraîche into the soup.
_______________
Ladle soup (chowder base) along with the fish and veg into the bowls with shellfish. Top with chopped parsley, chives or fennel fronds. Serve with lemon, salt + pepper to taste.
_______________
Ricotta topped with honey, toasted pine nuts, bee pollen, black pepper. Serve with baguette slices fried in a mix of schmaltz and olive oil. An easy hor d'oeuvre for dinner guests.

Mushroom Toast: heat olive oil or duck fat on medium-high, sear a mix of sliced cremini and wild mushrooms for about 5 min undisturbed, until slightly golden. Add sliced garlic or shallots, stir well with mushrooms, reduce heat to medium, add a tiny splash of white wine if you’d like, cook for about 3-4 minutes until everything has softened, fragrant and appetizingly golden. Before serving, stir in a dollop of crème fraîche, a squeeze of lemon, season with salt/pepper, chili pepper flakes, parsley. Top onto buttered toast, olive oil fried bread, or a carb of your choice.

Weeknight Pork Rib Chops:
poke 1-inch thick chops with a fork all over, marinate with a mixture of soy sauce, fish sauce, brown sugar, rice vinegar for about 30 min, longer if you have the time. Take chops out of marinade, and pan sear in grape seed oil in a preheated cast iron pan on medium-high for about 4-5 min a side. Adjust heat if things are getting too dark too fast. Don't forget to also sear the fat cap side. Let rest for about 10 min before serving with rice. Can also boil and reduce the remaining marinade into a dipping sauce. 😋🐷 Pasture-raised New England heritage pork chops from @savenorscambridge.

Bullet Potato: prick a russet potato all over with a fork, rub with oil and salt generously. Place directly on rack in a 450° oven for about an hour. Red snapper before roasting: Take a 1 ½ lb. whole red snapper, cleaned by your fishmonger, stuff the cavity with parsley, scallion, lemon and/or ginger slices. Place on a bed of scallions, drizzle generously with grapeseed or olive oil all over. Roast at 400ºF for about 20 min until cooked through (flakes easily). Bonus: the scallions underneath will crisp up and make an excellent mini condiment. Serve with rice and ginger-scallion sauce.
__________________
Ginger-scallion sauce: in a small bowl, combine your desired amount of grated ginger and minced scallions. Season to taste with kosher salt, white pepper, a small amount of fish sauce and a bit more oil (grapeseed or peanut oil are great options). Let sit for about 15-20 minutes, stir occasionally to combine flavors. Serve with roasted fish, poached chicken, congee, rice bowls, basically anything you want.

5-Spice Braised Beef Shanks Noodle Soup
__________________
In a heavy-bottom enameled cast iron dutch oven, heat neutral oil on high. Add in about 1 ½ - 2lbs. beef shanks, scatter on top crushed garlic, a few slices of ginger, 1 Tbsp szechuan peppercorn, 2 scallions cut 3-4 inches long. Cover and sear beef for about 4 minutes on each side until golden. Add in about a 1 cup of soy sauce, a bottle of red wine, 1 Tbsp of 5-spice powder, a couple star anise, a cinnamon stick, a large piece of rock sugar, a generous pinch of kosher salt and bring the mixture to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer for about 2-2 ½ hours, turning shanks occasionally. When shanks are done when they’re falling apart tender. Remove shanks from pot, let cool before cutting/slicing. Serve with noodles, rice or carbs of your choice, with vegetables, scallions, herbs of your choice, sesame oil and hot sauce.
__________________
To make the noodle soup, take the amount of cooking liquid you’d like and strain into a saucepan. Add a bit of hot water to dilute, season and taste to your liking. Bring to a slight boil. This will be your soup base. Cook noodles according to package directions, place chunks of shanks on top, pour on soup base, add in veg, scatter on herbs/scallions/hot peppers (or hot sauce), drizzle on sesame oil, serve.

Moulard duck legs from @savenorscambridge. Season with kosher salt, pepper, thyme and crushed bay leaf. Cover and refrigerate overnight. The next day, skin side down, render some fat out for ~20 min. on medium heat, then turn, skin side up, cover with foil and put in a 325° oven for 2 hours (middle rack), then remove foil and roast for another hour until everything is golden and cracklin'. Best served with a bracing salad, fried potatoes (preferably in duck fat), red wine or Lambrusco.

And don't you dare throw out the remaining duck fat.

Pasta with Shrimp & Boursin Cheese
__________________
Heat butter in pan, sauté shrimp with chopped garlic, about 3 min on one side and 1 min after flipping. Set aside and keep warm. Cook pasta of your choice in a pot. When done, reserve about a cup of pasta cooking water, drain pasta and return to pot. Crumble and stir in your desired amount of boursin cheese into the pasta. Add some cream and a bit of the pasta cooking water to loosen things up. Use tongs and toss pasta, making sure to stir well so the boursin combines with the cream and pasta cooking water to form a creamy sauce. Before serving, throw in some red chili pepper flakes, minced parsley and salt/pepper taste. Pile onto plate, top with sauteed shrimp and garlic. Squeeze lemon all over and enjoy. 🍤🍋

Spaghetti + Sunday Sauce
__________________
Disclaimer: this recipe/sauce is not 100% authentically Italian, but I can guarantee that it’s 100% tasty.
__________________
In an enameled cast-iron pot, deeply brown some cleaned chicken livers in grapeseed or olive oil. As they’re cooking, break them apart with wooden spoon into small bits. Be careful, the livers will splatter. You can also break them down further when you take them out of the pot. Set liver pieces aside. (If you’re grossed out by liver, skip this step!)
__________________
In the same pot, brown your desired amount of ground beef, I used about 2lbs. for plenty of leftovers. Remove beef from pot and using the rendered fat left behind, sweat some chopped onions, garlic (if you’d like), but don’t brown/burn them. Then add in some chopped carrots and celery. Continue to cook a bit longer until things have softened a bit. Deglaze with about ½ cup of red wine and make sure to stir and scrape up any browned bits left behind by the beef. Put beef and liver bits (if using) back in the pot. Add in a 30oz. can of good quality tomatoes along with the juices (San Marzanos are always key), crushing them with your hands as you put them in the pot, or if you don’t want to get your hands dirty, add in a can of already crushed tomatoes. If it’s tomato season, then use fresh chopped tomatoes. Add about 1 ½ cups of water and/or more red wine if things don’t look saucy enough.
__________________
Toss in a bay leaf and a decent hunk of Parmesan rind (super important ingredient), give everything a good stir and simmer away for at least 2 hours, longer if you have the time. I have simmered it overnight before only because I forgot to turn the stove off. 😅 The sauce was super flavorful, slowly bubbling away in the morning and the kitchen smelled amazing--but I don’t endorse doing this unless you can do so safely. When it’s time to eat, pluck out the bay leaf and Parmesan rind. Serve with your pasta of choice and a generous mound of grated Parmesan or Gruyère cheese on top. Salt and pepper to taste. Enjoy! 🍝😋

Smoked lamb tartar with horseradish sour cream and rye bread from Geiri, the local baker. Paired with smoked local beer (Reyktur Steðji). Perfect light lunch

Charred Radicchio Wedge Salad
______
Cut pancetta into 1/2-inch cubes, render out fat and cook in cast iron pan on medium heat until golden. Remove pancetta, leave drippings in pan, turn up heat to high and char quartered radicchio, about 1 to 1 1/2 min per side. Serve with reserved pancetta, chives, and a @vermontcreamery crème fraîche-lemon dressing.

Pasta with Tomato-Anchovy Sauce: before you turn your nose at anchovy, hear me out first.
__________________
Get a can of delicious salty anchovies from @traderjoes. It comes in a flat little yellow can. Pour out the fillets and accompanying olive oil into a medium saucepan. Toss in some crushed garlic and chili pepper flakes. Then turn the heat on low and using a wooden spoon, slowly and patiently smush the anchovy fillets into the oil until they have practically dissolved. (This may sounds nasty, but read on.) At this point, don’t be tempted to turn the heat on high because the anchovies will splatter, and you’ll burn your garlic. While still on low heat, put in a few good handfuls of cherry tomatoes and a splash of water. Cover saucepan and turn the heat up to medium/medium-high. Check occasionally to see if the tomatoes have burst. It should take about 5-8 minutes, continue to check on the tomatoes and carefully smash them with a wooden spoon if needed. The juices from the tomatoes will meld with the dissolved anchovies and olive oil to form a super tasty, balanced, umami-fied sauce. Toss in cooked pasta of your choice, and dinner is done in about 20 min--and most of the time, it’s pretty hands-off. No need to add additional salt because the anchovies should be salty enough. Chopped parsley on top if you feel like it.
__________________
Also If you don’t say anything, your dinner guests wouldn’t even know there are anchovies in their pasta.
😉🍝

Bacon, mushroom, leeks, potato frittata for the one-pan breakfast, brunch, lunch, or dinner.
________
Stir fry cooked bacon, mushrooms, leeks until softened. Add in sliced cooked potatoes. Distribute evenly. Turn heat down to low and add in whisked eggs (about 4-6, depending on how many you’re feeding/how hungry you are), toss in grated cheese if you like. Cook on low until bottom is sort of set, then transfer to the broiler and cook until top is set. Let sit for about 10 min before serving.

Brothy Beans for a chilly fall night: soak some dried @rancho_gordo beans overnight. In a heavy pot heat oil, cook anchovies, chili pepper flakes, garlic, shallots until anchovies are dissolved. Add beans, a Parmesan rind, and about 10 cups of water/chicken broth. Boil then reduce heat, simmer for about 3-4 hours until beans are creamy and falling apart. I added some frozen spinach at the end (optional) Season with salt and pepper, serve with a drizzle of cream and a handful of arugula.

Mix equal amounts of mirin, cooking rice wine, sugar and a bit more of miso in a small saucepan, heat on low and slowly whisk until everything is combined. Let cool.
__________________
Marinade any thin fish fillet (less than an inch thick) of your choice for 30 mins-1 hour. Typically 1 lb. of fish will feed two people. Before broiling, scrape off extra marinade, oil a sheet pan or oven-proof skillet, and lay fish on. Put under the broiler for about 4-5 minutes, check occasionally. When the fish flakes easily, it’s done. Carefully remove skillet or pan from oven. Serve fish with greens and lots of rice. Recipe adapted from Peter Meehan’s Lucky Peach 101 Easy Asian Recipes cookbook.

Sauteed dandelion greens: heat oil or duck fat or butter on medium-high heat, throw in some minced garlic, stir for 30 secs until fragrant, then toss in washed dandelion greens and sauteed until wilted. Sprinkle on a little lemon. The greens are pleasantly bitter and super good for you.
